work.p: This manuscript is likely an early draft of the following lines, which appeared in the 1860 poem "Proto-Leaf," eventually titled "Starting from Paumanok": "Behold! the body includes and is the meaning, the main concernâ€”and includes and is the Soul; / Whoever you are! how superb and how divine is your body, or any part of it" (1860, p. 17) and "All hold spiritual joys, and afterward loosen them, / How can the real body ever die, and be buried?" (1860, p. 16).

titleStmt.title: How can there be immortality
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. notesStmt.note: These lines bear a strong resemblance to the (eventual) second verse paragraph in section 6 of "Starting from Paumanok," first published in 1860 as "Proto-Leaf."

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: How can there be immortality
bibl.orgName: Papers of Walt Whitman (MSS 3829), Clifton Waller Barrett Library of American Literature, Albert H. Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.
A series of draft lines on the back of this manuscript leaf relate to the manuscript poem "Pictures."

lg.l:
All is Divine is the body person——it is all—
it is the soul also

A How else can there be immortality,
except through mortality?

How can the ultimate realities of visible things
be visible?

del.l: How else except in the though all things tend

lg.l: How can the real body ever die and be
